insights.insight: The ad industry pays $5+ CPM for probabilistic purchase inference; a cryptographically verified receipt confirms a transaction actually occurred — a distinction that makes every receipt-level signal structurally more valuable than anything currently traded on open exchanges.

With Chrome completing cookie deprecation and fingerprinting increasingly blocked by regulation, the $198K GMV already captured in verified receipts represents a class of purchase signal that has no direct substitute in the current cookieless stack.

Visa sees merchant category codes but not product names; Amazon sees its own orders but not Shopify or Costco; no single platform sees cross-ecosystem, product-level purchase behavior — which is precisely what receipt-level aggregation produces.

Brands that query the receipt dataset can see competitor overlap and stack combinations; brands that don't still have their receipts in the dataset — they're simply the only party not looking at the intelligence.

DKIM email authentication, built to stop spoofing, incidentally makes every vendor receipt email cryptographically verifiable — Anthropic, OpenAI, Stripe, Amazon, and others have already signed their receipts without designing them as commerce signals.

insights.topic: Market price for receipt data is unestablished
insights.insight: Credit card transaction data sells to hedge funds at $10M+/year but is identity-attached and lacks product-level detail; the receipt protocol has no active predicate queries yet, meaning the first brand to transact will set the reference price for a signal category that doesn't exist elsewhere.
